Package imagingbook.lib.util.resource

Class ResourceLocation

  • java.lang.Object
    • imagingbook.lib.util.resource.ResourceLocation
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    RLOC, RLOC
    public abstract class ResourceLocation
extends java.lang.Object

    Access to Java resources is not trivial and there are quite a few pitfalls to avoid. The aim of this class is to simplify access to resources contained in the local file system or inside JAR files.

    In ordinary Java, resources can be located relative to any class in the package hierarchy. Resources are found by their relative path and may be placed in nested sub-directories. This is error-prone since there is no way at compile time to ascertain that a required resource actually exists. If a resource does not exists this will cause a run-time error. The goal of this setup is to reduce this potential danger by a few restrictions:

    • A "resource location" (RL) is a flat directory (i.e., all resources are at the same level, no resources in sub-directories).
    • A RL contains the definition of a "marker class" which extends this class (ResourceLocation). This is to make sure that every resource location is also a Java package known to exist at compile time.
    • In principle, any legal name can be used for the marker class. We typically name such classes "RLOC" to stand out against ordinary Java classes.

    For example, a marker class in imagingbook.DATA.images.RLOC.java would be defined as follows:

     package imagingbook.DATA.images;
 public class RLOC extends ResourceLocation { }

    Nothing else is needed to mark the associated package as a resource location. Here is an example how to access the associated resources from some other class:

     ResourceLocation loc = new imagingbook.DATA.images.RLOC();
 Resource res = loc.getResource("boats.png");
 URI uri = res.getUri();
 InputStream strm = res.getStream();
 ...

    Specifically, an image can be opened (with ImageJ) as follows: 

     Resource res = loc.getResource("boats.png");
 ImagePlus im = res.openAsImage();
 ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
 ...
    Note that under the canonical Maven project structure, the associated file locations (package structure) are: 
     src/main/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/RLOC.java
 src/main/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png
 ... (other resources)
    or (if resources are used for testing only) 
     src/test/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/RLOC.java
 src/test/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png
 ... (other resources)

    Final note: To avoid marker classes showing up in the JavaDoc documentation, we use the following (internal) "convention" (currently under revision):

    • All root resource packages/directories are named DATA (deliberately upper-case to mark them as special packages, since Java package names are generally lower-case).
    • The pom.xml file contains the following entry in the configuration of the maven-javadoc-plugin:
      <excludePackageNames>*.DATA.*</excludePackageNames>
    Of course these packages could be named differently and excluded individually.
    Version:
    2021/07/28
